question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 1 The bladder is composed of ................ cells with dense plaques of .................. proteins.
explanation: The bladder is composed of umbrella cells with dense plaques of uroplakin proteins that contribute to the permeability barrier.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 2 The vasa recta branching from ................ are in association with the ......................
options: Efferent arterioles - loops of Henle and collecting ducts
answerText: Efferent arterioles - loops of Henle and collecting ducts
explanation: The vasa recta arise from efferent arterioles and are closely associated with loops of Henle and collecting ducts in the renal medulla.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 3 The distal tubule forms the ................... and the smooth muscle cells of afferent arteriole are modified as ..................
explanation: The distal tubule forms the macula densa, while the smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole are modified into juxtaglomerular granular cells.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 4 Which cells have renin granules?
explanation: Juxtaglomerular cells in the afferent arteriole contain renin granules, which are involved in blood pressure regulation.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 5 Slit diaphragms are modified and specialized .................. composed of ..................
explanation: Slit diaphragms in podocytes are specialized tight junctions composed of nephrin, which play a key role in glomerular filtration.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 6 How late does the formation of nephrons continue? and, When the lobulation of the fetal kidney disappears?
explanation: Nephron formation continues until birth, and lobulation of the fetal kidney disappears after birth.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 7 Incomplete division of the ureteric bud can lead to ................ and, the .................. can form if the degeneration of the allantois is not completed.
explanation: Incomplete division of the ureteric bud can result in supernumerary kidneys, and failure of allantois degeneration can lead to a urachal cyst.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 8 Which abnormality results from fusion of the caudal poles of the kidneys?
explanation: Fusion of the caudal poles of the kidneys results in a horseshoe kidney, which is often trapped under the inferior mesenteric artery.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 9 Which of the following is a remnant of the allantois?
explanation: The median umbilical ligament is a remnant of the allantois, extending from the bladder to the umbilicus.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 10 Which duct is NOT associated with urinary system development?
explanation: The paramesonephric duct is involved in the development of the female reproductive system, not the urinary system.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 11 The .................. can be a symptom of bilateral renal agenesis.
explanation: Oligohydramnios (reduced amniotic fluid) is a classic symptom of bilateral renal agenesis due to lack of fetal urine production.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 12 What gives rise to transitional epithelium of the bladder and mesonephros respectively?
explanation: The transitional epithelium of the bladder arises from endoderm, while the mesonephros is derived from mesoderm.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 13 Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) affects on ................. and the rate of Na+ absorption from .................. is regulated by aldosterone.
explanation: ADH acts on collecting ducts to promote water reabsorption, while aldosterone increases Na+ reabsorption in distal tubules.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 14 The ................. of .............. helps maintain acid-base balance.
explanation: Intercalated cells in the collecting duct regulate acid-base balance by secreting hydrogen ions or bicarbonate.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 15 Which of the following is derived from metanephric cap and ureteric bud respectively?
explanation: The loop of Henle is derived from the metanephric cap, and the collecting duct arises from the ureteric bud.

question: First Batch (2024-09-22) Retake Exam - Dr. Golshan - Question 16 The .................. urethra passes through corpus spongiosum and is lined by .................. epithelium.
options: Penile - stratified columnar and pseudostratified columnar
answerText: Penile - stratified columnar and pseudostratified columnar
explanation: The penile urethra passes through the corpus spongiosum and is lined by stratified columnar and pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 1 The collecting duct is composed of ................ cells with .................. proteins.
explanation: The principal cells in the collecting duct express aquaporins, which are water channels regulated by antidiuretic hormone (ADH).

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 2 The penile urethra passes through ..................... and is lined by .................. epithelium.
options: Corpus spongiosum - stratified columnar and pseudostratified columnar
answerText: Corpus spongiosum - stratified columnar and pseudostratified columnar
explanation: The penile urethra passes through the corpus spongiosum and is primarily lined by stratified columnar and pseudostratified columnar epithelium.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 3 Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) affects on ................. and the rate of Na+ absorption from .................. is regulated by aldosterone.
explanation: ADH increases water reabsorption in the collecting ducts, while aldosterone regulates Na+ absorption in the distal tubules.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 4 The ...................... branching from ................ are in association with the loops of Henle and collecting ducts.
explanation: The vasa recta arise from the efferent arterioles and closely follow the loops of Henle and collecting ducts, contributing to the countercurrent exchange system.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 5 The distal tubule forms the ................... and the smooth muscle cells of afferent arteriole are modified as ..................
explanation: The macula densa is a specialized region of the distal tubule, and the juxtaglomerular granular cells of the afferent arteriole secrete renin.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 6 The .................. of .............. helps maintain acid-base balance.
explanation: Intercalated cells in the collecting duct secrete hydrogen ions and reabsorb bicarbonate to regulate acid-base balance.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 7 Which cells have renin granules?
explanation: Juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney contain renin granules and release renin in response to low blood pressure or sympathetic stimulation.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 8 Slit diaphragms are modified and specialized .................. composed of ..................
explanation: Slit diaphragms are specialized tight junctions between podocyte foot processes and are composed primarily of nephrin.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 9 Which of the following is derived from the metanephric cap and ureteric bud respectively?
explanation: The loop of Henle arises from the metanephric cap, while the collecting duct is derived from the ureteric bud.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 10 How late does the formation of nephrons continue? And, when does the lobulation of the fetal kidney disappear?
explanation: Nephron formation is completed by birth, while the lobulated appearance of the fetal kidney disappears after birth.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 11 Incomplete division of the ureteric bud can lead to ................ and the ................ can form if the degeneration of the allantois is not completed.
explanation: Incomplete division of the ureteric bud may result in supernumerary kidneys, and failure of allantois degeneration can lead to a urachal cyst.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 12 Which one results in horseshoe kidney?
options: Abnormal branching of the ureteric bud
Fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys
Fusion of the upper poles of the kidneys
answerText: Fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys
explanation: Horseshoe kidney occurs when the lower poles of the kidneys fuse during development and fail to ascend properly.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 13 Which of the following is a remnant of the allantois?
explanation: The median umbilical ligament is a remnant of the allantois, which connects the fetal bladder to the umbilicus.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 14 Which duct is NOT associated with urinary system development?
explanation: The paramesonephric (Müllerian) duct is primarily involved in the development of the female reproductive system and does not contribute to the urinary system.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 15 The .................. can be a symptom of bilateral renal agenesis.
explanation: Bilateral renal agenesis results in oligohydramnios due to the absence of fetal urine output, which contributes to the amniotic fluid.

question: Second Batch (2024-12-1) - Histo. & Embryo. - Dr. Golshan - Question 16 What gives rise to the muscle of the bladder and mesonephros respectively?
explanation: The muscle of the bladder and the mesonephros are both derived from mesoderm during embryological development.
